text.*:
An aptronym, aptonym or euonym is a personal name aptly or peculiarly suited to its owner.

Contents

  • 1 History
  • 2 Notable examples
    • 2.1 Inaptronyms
  • 3 See also
  • 4 References
  • 5 External links

History[edit]

The Encyclopædia Britannica attributes the term to Franklin P. Adams, a writer who coined it as an anagram of patronym, to emphasize "apt".[1]

According to Frank Nuessel, in The Study of Names (1992), an aptonym is the term used for "people whose names and occupations or situations (e.g., workplace) have a close correspondence."

In the book What's in a Name? (1996), author Paul Dickson cites a long list of aptronyms originally compiled by Professor Lewis P. Lipsitt, of Brown University.[2] Psychologist Carl Jung wrote in his book Synchronicity that there was a "sometimes quite grotesque coincidence between a man's name and his peculiarities".[3]

Nominative determinism is a hypothesis which suggests a causal relationship based on the idea that people tend to be attracted to areas of work that fit their name.

Notable examples[edit]

  • Jules Angst, German professor of psychiatry, who has published works about anxiety[4]
  • Michael Ball, football player[5]
  • Lonzo Ball, basketball player
  • Colin Bass, British bassist in the rock band Camel[4]
  • Lance Bass, bass singer for the American pop boy band NSYNC[6]
  • Sara Blizzard, meteorologist (television weather presenter) for the BBC[4]
  • Usain Bolt, Jamaican sprinter[7]
  • Rosalind Brewer, executive at Starbucks and a former director at Molson Coors Brewing Company[8][9]
  • Margaret Court, Australian tennis player[5]
  • Thomas Crapper, sanitary engineer[5][10]
  • Josh Earnest, the third press secretary for the Obama Administration (Stephen Colbert observed, "What a name for a press secretary. Josh Earnest. His name literally means, 'Just kidding, but seriously.'"[11])
  • W. L. Edge, mathematician and author of The Theory of Ruled Surfaces.[12]
  • Cecil Fielder and Prince Fielder, baseball players[13]
  • Franz Fischler, former European Union Commissioner for Fisheries
  • Amy Freeze, American meteorologist[14]
  • Theodore Gill, American ichthyologist
  • Igor Judge, English judge and Lord Chief Justice[15]
  • Chris Moneymaker, American poker player and 2003 World Series of Poker champion[16]
  • Francine Prose, American novelist[17]
  • Marilyn vos Savant, American columnist who has been cited for having the world's highest recorded IQ[18]
  • Lionel Tiger, anthropologist known for his writings on animal behaviour and its relation to human behaviour.[12]
  • Anthony Weiner, American politician involved in sexting scandals[14]
  • William Wordsworth, English poet and advocate for the extension of British copyright law[19][20][5]


Inaptronyms[edit]

Some aptronyms are ironic rather than descriptive, being called inaptronyms by Gene Weingarten of the Washington Post.[21] A notable example is the former Archbishop of Manila, Jaime Sin who in 1976 was made a cardinal by Pope Paul VI, thus becoming known as "Cardinal Sin".[4]

  • Frank Beard, an American musician who, until recently, was the only member of rock band ZZ Top without a beard[22]
  • Don Black, white supremacist[4]
  • Peter Bowler, cricketer (in fact, primarily a batsman)[4]
  • Samuel Foote, a comic actor who lost a leg in a horseriding accident in 1766, and made jokes on stage about "Foote and leg, and leg and foot"[23]
  • Danielle Outlaw, Chief of Police at Portland Police Bureau[24]
  • Larry Playfair, NHL defenseman known for his fighting[25]

See also[edit]

  • -onym
